Graphical abstract Highlights ► Ultrasonic spray pyrolysis method was used to prepare nanostructured NiS2. ► Pure phase cubic NiS2 submicrometer porous spheres were synthesized. ► High surface area of 300m2 g−1 was observed for the NiS2 spheres. ► Hydrodesulfurization catalytic activity was tested using dibenzothiophene (DBT). ► A first order rate reaction rate constant of 1.51×10−4 s−1gcata−1 at 320°C was observed. Nanostructured NiS2 has attracted interest due to its wide applications and special properties. Synthesis of a pure phase NiS2 in a single step has been a challenge. In this work, a new method for direct synthesis of uniform NiS2/SiO2 sub microspheres has been developed by ultrasonic spray pyrolysis. Colloidal silica was used as a sacrificial template to create the porous structure. After silica removal, hollow, porous NiS2 nano spheres were obtained. The product was characterized by using scanning electron microscopy, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm. XRD confirmed the formation of single phase pyrite NiS2. It was found that the porous spherical NiS2 has a surface area of ca. 300m2 g−1. The HDS catalytic activity of NiS2 was evaluated using a model compound, dibenzothiophene (DBT). It showed a first order reaction rate constant of 1.51×10−4 s−1 gcata−1 at 320°C for HDS of DBT, which is significantly promising for further exploration. Keywords Nickel disulfide Ultrasonic spray pyrolysis Hydrodesulfurization Dibenzothiophene 1 Introduction Transition metal semiconductor chalcogenides are attracting wide interest because of their versatile optical [1], magnetic [2] and catalytic [3] properties. In nanometer scale, these properties are highly influenced by the size, shape and dimensionality of these materials [4,5]. Important transition metal sulfides such as cadmium sulfide [6], zinc sulfide [7,8], manganese sulfide [9], silver sulfide [9], iron sulfide [10], nickel sulfide [11,12] and many phases of copper sulfides [13] have been investigated extensively. These sulfides have broad field of potential applications including cathode materials in rechargeable lithium batteries [13], IR detectors [14], catalyst for photogalvanic cells [15], a possible transformation toughener [16], paramagnetic–antiferromagnetic phase-changing material [17], catalysts in the degradation of organic dyes [18] or hydrodesulfurization catalysts [19]. Among the family of metal sulfides, nickel sulfides also have attracted much interest as they can form various phases such as NiS, α-Ni3+x S2, β-Ni3S2, Ni7S6, Ni9S8, Ni3S4, and NiS2. Kullerud and Yund [20] first reported the nickel sulfide system, followed by others [21–24]. NiS2 in particular comes in two main phases, a triclinic phase [25] and a cubic phase [26]. Cubic pyrite NiS2 possesses interesting electronic, optical and magnetic characteristics [27–29]. Heavy oil, extra heavy oil, and oil sands bitumen comprise of 70% of the world's total oil resources. These non conventional sources of oil are becoming more important as conventional oil reserves deplete rapidly [30]. However, non conventional oils contain high levels of contaminants including high sulfur content. High sulfur content is the main concern for nonconventional oil. To reduce the sulfur content to a regulated level, the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process is indispensable in hydrotreating sulfur-containing fractions during petroleum refining and heavy oil upgrading. Nickel sulfide is an active component in hydrotreating catalysts, which improves the catalytic activity of MoS2 by forming NiMoS x . Catalytic activity of nickel sulfide alone was also investigated. Welters et al. [19] prepared sulfide NiNaY using ion-exchange followed by sulfiding, and found that the activity of the sulfided NiNaY depends on the preparation method and pretreatment conditions. They also found that the support affects the catalytic activity. Zeolite-Y supported Ni sulfide has a higher activity than its alumina supported counterpart, and performs comparably to its carbon supported counterpart [19]. To achieve a better understanding of the catalytic activity of nickel sulfide toward hydrodesulfurization, it is important to study the unsupported nickel sulfide, which, to the best of our knowledge, has not been reported. There are several methods to prepare NiS2, each having advantages and drawbacks. The simplest one is by direct combination of the elements. Crystalline transition metal dichalcogenides can be synthesized at high temperature (500–1200°C) by direct stoichiometric combination of constituent elements in evacuated silica tubes [31]. Delafosse and Barret reported the preparation of nickel disulfide from nickel sulfate and hydrogen sulfide at 230°C [32]. Sanchez et al. [33] produced thin films of NiS2 by thermal sulfidation of flash nickel layers on glass substrates at room temperature. Kaner et al. [34] reported the rapid solid-state synthesis of NiS2 from the precursor of high-valence metal halides. Recently various reports on the preparation of nanostructured NiS2 have been published. Dendritic NiS2 nanostructures of cubic phase NiS2 have been synthesized using γ irradiation method [35]. Mono dispersed cubic shaped NiS2 and NiS2 dodecahedrons, microspheres were produced by a solvothermal synthesis [12]. NiS2 nanostructures were also synthesized by chemical vapor transport technique [36], solid state reaction [37], soft solution process [11], chemical nanofabrication [38], hydrothermal method [24,39], solvothermal process [40] and even by using metal polysulfide precursor [41]. Most of these methods however, produce ill-defined, non-stoichiometric or poorly crystallized NiS2, with relatively small surface area. Hollow and/or porous spherical products would have advantages over solid spheres and other nanostructures due to their higher specific surface area, better permeability and unique surface properties [42]. As a result, they are considered better candidates for a broad range of applications in photonic crystals, 3D macroporous materials, drug delivery sensors and catalysts [42–44]. There are several methods to produce such nano/microspheres [45]. However, most of these methods have poor yield, impure/multiphase products etc. [46]. Preparation of pure phase, monodispersed nano/microspheres with such a uniform morphology is a challenge. One promising approach is ultrasonic spray pyrolysis (USP), an aerosol synthetic technique that can produce micro- and nanostructured products in a single step. USP has been used to synthesize catalysts, metal oxides, silica, porous carbons, and nanocomposite materials [47–56]. It is a convenient method to continuously prepare uniformly distributed micrometer or submicrometer sized spherical products in large scale. Generally, USP produces products with a lower surface area. To overcome this problem, nanosized silica was used as a sacrificial template to create a porous structure in the submicrospheres [55]. In this work we used the USP method to synthesize well defined crystalline porous NiS2 spheres with high surface area (300m2 g−1) at relatively low temperature. To the best of our knowledge this is the first report on the synthesis of porous submicrometer size spheres of pure cubic phase NiS2 with such a high surface area. Its catalytic activity toward HDS was tested. It was found that the porous NiS2 submicrospheres could be a promising HDS catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. NiCl2·6H2O and Na2S2O3·5H2O were obtained from Sigma–Aldrich, and colloidal silica was obtained from AzkoNobel/Eka, 35wt% of silica suspended in water, particle diameter ca. 3nm. 2.2 Synthesis of porous NiS2 submicrospheres The USP procedure for the synthesis of nanomaterials was reported elsewhere [57]. Fig. 1 illustrates the preparation process of the porous NiS2 microspheres. In a typical synthesis procedure, a designated amount of NiCl2·6H2O and Na2S2O3·5H2O were dissolved in 800mL deionized (DI) water to make a solution containing 0.04M NiCl2 and 0.08M Na2S2O3. After being stirred for 10min, 4% colloidal silica was added slowly and the resultant solution was stirred for another 20min. The solution was then loaded to an ultrasonic spray pyrolysis (USP) ultra-sonic cell. Fig. 2 shows the USP equipment set up, which consists of a solution bath, an ultrasonic atomizer, a tube furnace, and bubblers as a product collector. The system was purged with Ar for 30min. The solution was then nebulized with an ultrasonic atomizer (2.4MHz, Sonaer Inc., Farmingdale, NY). The aerosol mist was carried by Ar (flow rate: 5Lmin−1) through a tube furnace at 300°C. The product was collected, filtered, washed with DI water, and dried at room temperature. The silica component in these NiS2–SiO2 composite particles was then removed by etching in 5% HF solution. The final product was centrifuged and washed for several times with ethanol and DI water followed by drying under vacuum at 70°C for 12h. 2.3 Physical characterization The product was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and N2-sorptometry. SEM images of the product were taken using an FEI Dual Beam Strata 235 scanning electron microscope operating at 5kV. The transmission electron micrographs were taken on a JEOL 2011 scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) operating at 200keV. The micrographs were recorded digitally using a CCD camera (Gatan 4k×4k Ultrascan). TEM/EDX elemental analysis of the product was done on the same instrument using an EDAX (Genesis) energy dispersive X-ray system. The phase of the nickel sulfide was confirmed by XRD. The XRD patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation at 40kV, 20mA and a scanning rate of 0.04 2θ s−1. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm was taken on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument using a static adsorption procedure. 3-Point Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller (BET) analysis was employed to obtain surface area. The sample was outgassed at 70°C for 8h before the measurements. 2.4 Hydrotreating test The porous NiS2 nanospheres were evaluated using a model compound dibenzothiophene (DBT) in a 300mL autoclave reactor. Before testing, the catalyst (1g) was sulfided with dimethyl disulfide (DMDS) (5mL) at 350°C for 1h according to a procedure described in the literature [58]. Then 100g of solution containing 1wt% DBT, 85wt% toluene, and 14% dodecane was loaded into the autoclave under N2 protection. After purging with N2 and H2, the reactor was pressurized with H2 to 500psi. Under stirring at 600rpm, the reactor was heated to 320°C and kept at this temperature for 4h; then it was cooled down to room temperature. Samples were taken from the autoclave for analysis during the reaction, at 0min (the time when temperature reached 320°C), 20min, 40min, 1h, 1.5h, 2h, and 4h (at the reaction temperature). Samples taken from the autoclave were analyzed using different methods to determine the chemical and elemental compositions. Sulfur content in the original feed oil and hydrotreated products was determined by sulfur/nitrogen analyzer (9000 series, Antek Instruments Inc.). A detailed sulfur compound composition was analyzed by gas chromatography (Varian 450) equipped with a HP-1 capillary column (15m×0.20mm×0.33μm, max temperature: 325°C) and a pulsed flame photometric detector (PFPD). Other compounds in the product were identified by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (Shimadzu GCMS-QP5000) with a weak-polarity column Agilent J&W HP-5 (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm, max temperature: 325°C). The hydrogenation of toluene in terms of production of methylcyclohexane was tested by gas chromatography (Varian 450) with non-polarity capillary column Agilent J&W VF-1ms (15m×0.25mm×0.25μm, max temperature: 325°C) and a hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure of nickel disulfide submicrostructure Fig. 3A and B shows SEM and TEM images of the spherical NiS2–SiO2 composite, respectively. It can be seen that submicrometer sized spheres (500±200nm) of NiS2–SiO2 composite were produced. Due to the presence of multiple nucleation sites in the precursor droplet, USP generally produces polycrystalline spherical products [59]. The electron diffraction pattern (ED) (not shown) of the product shows a continuous ring with fine spots confirming a polycrystalline material composed of nano crystallites. EDX analysis of the composite confirmed the presence of nickel and sulfur, with a molar ratio of 1:2 (Fig. 4 ). Fig. 5 shows the XRD pattern of the synthesized product. It reveals the formation of single phase NiS2 at relatively lower temperature (300°C). Diffraction peaks of NiS2 were observed at 2θ (°)=27.1 (111), 31.5 (200), 35.3 (210), 38.8 (211), 45.1 (220), 53.5 (311), 56.5 (222), 58.6 (023), 61.1 (321) and 72.5 (331), respectively. All these diffraction peaks can be assigned to a cubic nickel disulfide, consistent with reported data for nickel disulfide (NiS2, JCPDS Card No. 01-088-1709, a =5.6873Å). Other peaks present in the diffraction pattern can be attributed to SiO2, present in the synthesized NiS2–SiO2 composite. The sharp diffraction peaks confirm the good crystalline nature of the product. Fig. 6A shows the TEM micrograph of SiO2-free spherical network of NiS2 after HF treatment. The spherical morphology was not damaged in the SiO2 removal process. Fig. 6A also shows the presence of a trace amount of NaCl. Pyrolysis of the precursor solution mixture for this reaction produced sodium chloride as the major byproduct. A closer look at the same spherical structure (Fig. 6B) reveals presence of pores on the surface of the sphere, and such spheres are made up of nanocrystalline NiS2 particles of average size of 10–15nm. EDX analysis of the same product showed the presence of only nickel, sulfur and trace amount of oxygen (Fig. 7 ), which confirms successful leaching of SiO2 from the composite material. Fig. 8 shows N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms for the NiS2–SiO2 composite (A) and SiO2-free spherical NiS2 (B). Total surface area of both materials was calculated by BET method. Surface area of the NiS2–SiO2 composite was found to be 40m2 g−1 while it was 300m2 g−1 for the silica free NiS2. This was expected as removal of silica from the spherical composite material made it hollow with numerous pores in the sphere. Adsorption isotherm for silica-free NiS2 shows a curve with a step at relative pressure >0.8 with a small plateau. By extrapolating the plateau to the Y-axis, the pore volume can be calculated from the intercept at Y-axis by converting the adsorbed volume to liquid N2 volume. The pore volume was found to be 0.93cm3 g−1 for the silica free NiS2, and 0.03cm3 g−1 for the NiS2–SiO2 composite. The high BET surface area and large pore volume of the material coupled with such type of adsorption isotherm is indicative of the presence of micro and macroporosity in the product. 3.2 HDS activity of the catalyst As environmental regulations on sulfur content in on-road fossil fuel such as gasoline and diesel become more stringent, deep desulfurization of these fossil fuels is needed. For example, EPA regulations have reduced non-road diesel fuel sulfur from 500ppm at 2007 to 15ppm at 2010; further reduction might be needed in the future [60,61]. Sulfur compounds in the fossil fuels after conventional desulfurization are refractory DBT and its alkyl substitutes especially 4,6-dimethyl dibenzothiophene [62–64]. Thus HDS of DBT and its derivatives is the main focus of deep HDS. Here we were focusing on the removal of DBT using unsupported nanostructured NiS2 porous spheres. The model oil used in the HDS test was comprised of DBT, toluene and dodecane. During the HDS reaction, sulfur can be removed via two parallel routes [65] (Scheme 1 ). The first route involves direct desulfurization (DDS) where biphenyl is the end product due to the CS bond breakage through a Hofmann elimination of the dihydrogenated product [66]. On the other hand, the second route involves hydrogenation (HYD) of one of the benzene rings of the DBT producing tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (TH-DBT) in the first step and eventually further desulfurized to cyclohexyl benzene [63,67,68]. In the presence of unpromoted and cobalt promoted MoS2/Al2O3 catalysts, HDS of DBT follows the DDS pathway. However alkyl substitution in 4- and 6-positions of DBT considerably slows it down while promoting the HYD pathway [69–71]. Table 1 shows the distribution of DBT and TH-DBT during the hydrotreatment process obtained using GC-PFPD analysis. After two hours of hydrotreating process, the DBT content in the model oil was found to be 685.8ppm while the TH-DBT content was 68.9ppm. At the end of four hours (4h) of the HDS process the DBT content was 208.7ppm while that of TH-DBT was 18.7ppm. This indicates that Th-DBT content is very low in the hydrotreating process. This low content of TH-DBT during the course of the hydrotreatment indicates that the HDS process either produced only a minor fraction of TH-DBT or the TH-DBT is an active intermediate product. To determine the HDS mechanisms, other HYD products should also be considered. During the hydrotreating test several reactions involving the model oil and NiS2 catalyst can occur. As shown in Scheme 1, DDS and HYD pathways could occur resulting in DBT desulfurization. Also toluene hydrogenation and polymerization could also happen. Fig. 9 is the GC–MS spectrum, showing the presence of different compounds at room temperature after the HDS procedure. It shows the presence of biphenyl, TH-DBT, and other compounds as listed in Fig. 9. Biphenyl is a product of the DDS pathway while bicyclohexyl, cyclohexyl benzene, and TH-DBT are products of the HYD pathway. Although biphenyl can be further hydrogenated into cyclohexyl benzene, this reaction is slow compared with the DDS and HYD reactions [72]. Thus the biphenyl concentration represents the DDS pathway, and the total of bicyclohexyl, cyclohexyl benzene, and TH-DBT represent the HYD pathway. From Fig. 8, it can be seen that the ratio of the two sets of products is about 1:1, indicating that this NiS2 catalyzed HDS of DBT through both HYD and DDS pathways. Polymerization of toluene accounts for the compounds present in regions 11 and 12 of the GC–MS. The hydrogenation of toluene produced methylcyclohexane and other products which were analyzed by GC-FID. Such products comprised 1.05% of the total organic content of the post HDS product. Table 2 shows the total sulfur content (ppm) in the feed at different times during the hydrotreatment as well as DBT conversion of NiS2 toward HDS. HDS conversion was calculated based on the initial time=0min sample. After 4h hydrotreating, HDS conversion reached 86.6%, higher than that observed with a novel NiMoS2/SiO2 catalyst recently developed in our group and tested under the same condition [73]. This high HDS conversion indicates this NiS2 is a promising HDS catalyst. Overall oil recovery ratio at the end of the test was found to be 93% which is quite reasonable. The kinetics of the NiS2 catalyzed HDS were analyzed from sulfur content change with time assuming the reaction is first order in DBT [74]. Fig. 10 shows the plot of logarithm of sulfur content versus time. A linear relationship was observed. From the slope, the reaction rate constant of the NiS2 catalyzed HDS reaction was calculated to be 1.51×10−4 s−1 gcata−1 which is much higher than nanostructured NiMoS2/SiO2 HDS catalyst synthesized by the same group [74]. As in the literature, pseudo-zero order reaction was used to study the reaction kinetics [55], to make a fair comparison, DBT concentration change was also plotted versus time. A nearly straight line (R =0.964) can be obtained (not shown). From the slope the pseudo-zero reaction rate constant can be calculated to be 3.36×10−4 mols−1 gcata−1 or 7.0×10−4 mols−1 gmetal−1. Although reaction rate constant for unsupported NiS2 catalyzed HDS of DBT was not found in the literature, Welter [19] reported a reaction rate constant of 1.28×10−5 mols−1 gmetal−1 (or 23×10−3 m3 kg−1 s−1 in the paper) for the HDS of thiophene catalyzed by sulfided NiNaY (8% metal) at 400°C, and Skrabalak and Suslick [55] reported a rate constant of 2.17×10−5 mols−1 gmetal−1 (or 12×1018 mols−1 gmetal−1 in their paper) for the HDS of thiophene catalyzed by Co-promoted mesoporous MoS2 spheres (prepared by USP) at 350°C. It was reported that thiophene could be 13 times easier desulfurized than DBT. Assuming the relative HDS reactivity of DBT is 100, that of thiophene is 1330 [75]. Considering the temperature (320°C) used in this work is lower than the literature, DBT was used instead of thiophene, and the high reaction rate constant was obtained, the unsupported porous NiS2 showed significantly higher HDS activity, demonstrating its potential application as a promising HDS catalyst. 4 Conclusions Nanostructured porous NiS2 submicrometer spheres were successfully synthesized using the USP method. This synthesis procedure provides a single step, continuous and scalable route to make NiS2/SiO2 which eventually produced template-free NiS2. With the help of this method highly crystalline cubic nickel disulfide was obtained. The synthesized catalysts have uniform Ni and S distribution and a uniform sphere size of 500±200nm. Testing with DBT showed that the catalysts have reasonable HDS activity. The reaction rate constant of HDS for this catalyst was determined to be 1.51×10−4 s−1 gcata−1 at 320°C. coredata.dc:description: Nanostructured NiS2 has attracted interest due to its wide applications and special properties. Synthesis of a pure phase NiS2 in a single step has been a challenge. In this work, a new method for direct synthesis of uniform NiS2/SiO2 sub microspheres has been developed by ultrasonic spray pyrolysis. Colloidal silica was used as a sacrificial template to create the porous structure. After silica removal, hollow, porous NiS2 nano spheres were obtained. The product was characterized by using scanning electron microscopy, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm. XRD confirmed the formation of single phase pyrite NiS2. It was found that the porous spherical NiS2 has a surface area of ca. 300m2 g−1. The HDS catalytic activity of NiS2 was evaluated using a model compound, dibenzothiophene (DBT). It showed a first order reaction rate constant of 1.51×10−4 s−1 gcata−1 at 320°C for HDS of DBT, which is significantly promising for further exploration.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis, characterization and evaluation of unsupported porous NiS2 sub-micrometer spheres as a potential hydrodesulfurization catalyst
